levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can convert between basic metric units (e.g. cm to m, g to kg) using simple multiplication or division by 10, 100, 1000.
levels.example_task: Convert 3.5 km to metres.
common_errors: Dividing instead of multiplying when converting to smaller units
Not knowing the conversion factors between metric units

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converts between a range of metric units including area and volume units, understanding why area units use squared conversion factors.
levels.example_task: Convert 2.4 m² to cm².
common_errors: Converting by ×100 instead of ×10,000 (not squaring the linear factor)
Confusing m² with m when converting

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Converts fluently between all standard units including time, area, volume and compound units, choosing the most efficient method.
levels.example_task: Convert 72 km/h to m/s.
levels.example_response: 72 km/h = 72,000 m / 3600 s = 20 m/s. Shortcut: divide by 3.6 (since 1 m/s = 3.6 km/h). 72 ÷ 3.6 = 20 m/s.
common_errors: Multiplying by 3.6 instead of dividing
Converting distance and time separately but combining them incorrectly

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves problems requiring multi-step unit conversions and understands dimensional analysis as a systematic approach.
levels.example_task: A tap fills a container at 0.5 litres per second. How many cubic centimetres per minute is this?
levels.example_response: 0.5 L/s = 500 cm³/s (since 1 L = 1000 cm³). Per minute: 500 × 60 = 30,000 cm³/min. Using dimensional analysis: 0.5 L/s × 1000 cm³/L × 60 s/min = 30,000 cm³/min.
common_errors: Not knowing that 1 litre = 1000 cm³
Forgetting to convert the time unit as well as the volume unit

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands what a scale means and can use a simple scale to find real distances from a map.
levels.example_task: On a map, 1 cm represents 5 km. Two towns are 3.5 cm apart. What is the real distance?
common_errors: Dividing instead of multiplying
Not reading the scale correctly from the map

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses scale factors to create or interpret scale drawings, converting between real and scaled measurements in both directions.
levels.example_task: A room is 6 m by 4.5 m. Draw a scale diagram using a scale of 1:100.
levels.example_response: Scale 1:100 means 1 cm represents 100 cm = 1 m. So the drawing is 6 cm by 4.5 cm.
common_errors: Confusing which way the scale works (is the drawing bigger or smaller?)
Not converting units before applying the scale

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies scale factors to areas and volumes, understanding that area scales by k² and volume by k³.
levels.example_task: A model car is built at scale 1:20. The real car is 4 m long and has a windscreen area of 1.2 m². Find the model's length and windscreen area.
common_errors: Dividing the area by 20 instead of 20²
Not distinguishing between linear, area and volume scale factors

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves complex real-world problems involving scale, including those requiring scale conversion between different representations and critical evaluation of scale accuracy.
levels.example_task: Two maps show the same region. Map A has scale 1:50,000 and Map B has scale 1:25,000. A distance is 6 cm on Map A. How long is it on Map B?
levels.example_response: Real distance = 6 × 50,000 = 300,000 cm = 3 km. On Map B: 300,000 ÷ 25,000 = 12 cm. Alternatively: Map B is at twice the scale of Map A, so distances are doubled: 6 × 2 = 12 cm.
common_errors: Halving instead of doubling (confusing which map is more detailed)
Not finding the real distance as an intermediate step

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can express one quantity as a fraction of another when the context is straightforward.
levels.example_task: There are 8 red balls and 20 balls in total. What fraction are red?
levels.example_response: 8/20 = 2/5 are red.
common_errors: Writing 8/12 (using the other colour instead of the total)
Not simplifying the fraction

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Expresses quantities as fractions including improper fractions, and simplifies using HCF.
levels.example_task: Express 45 minutes as a fraction of 2 hours.
common_errors: Not converting to the same units first
Expressing as 45/2 instead of converting hours to minutes

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Uses fraction-of to solve comparison and proportion problems, including connecting to percentage and ratio representations.
levels.example_task: A school has 600 pupils. 240 study French, 180 study Spanish, and the rest study German. Express each as a fraction and a percentage.
common_errors: Not checking the fractions sum to 1 (or percentages to 100%)
Making conversion errors between fractions and percentages

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies fractional reasoning to complex multi-step problems and understands the algebra of proportional relationships.
levels.example_task: In a jar, 2/5 of the sweets are red and 1/3 of the remainder are blue. What fraction are blue?
levels.example_response: Red = 2/5. Remainder = 1 - 2/5 = 3/5. Blue = 1/3 of 3/5 = 1/5. So 1/5 of all sweets are blue.
common_errors: Computing 1/3 of the total instead of 1/3 of the remainder
Not identifying 'remainder' as 3/5 of the total

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands that a ratio compares two or more quantities and can write a ratio from a description.
levels.example_task: In a class of 30, there are 18 girls and 12 boys. Write the ratio of girls to boys.
levels.example_response: Girls to boys = 18:12 = 3:2.
common_errors: Writing 18:30 instead of 18:12 (using the total instead of the other part)
Not simplifying the ratio

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Simplifies ratios by dividing by common factors and converts between ratio and fraction forms.
levels.example_task: Simplify the ratio 45:60:75.
levels.example_response: Divide all parts by 15: 45:60:75 = 3:4:5.
common_errors: Simplifying only two of the three parts
Not finding the HCF of all three numbers

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves problems using ratio, converting between ratio, fraction and percentage representations as needed.
levels.example_task: Purple paint is made by mixing red and blue in the ratio 3:5. How much blue is needed to mix with 12 litres of red?
levels.example_response: Red:Blue = 3:5. If red = 12 litres, the scale factor is 12/3 = 4. Blue = 5 × 4 = 20 litres.
common_errors: Dividing 12 by 5 instead of by 3
Not identifying which part of the ratio corresponds to which colour

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves complex ratio problems involving changing ratios, combining ratios, and algebraic ratio reasoning.
levels.example_task: The ratio of cats to dogs in a shelter is 3:5. After 6 more cats arrive, the ratio becomes 3:4. How many animals were there originally?
levels.example_response: Originally: cats = 3k, dogs = 5k. After: cats = 3k + 6, dogs = 5k. New ratio: (3k+6)/5k = 3/4. Cross-multiply: 4(3k+6) = 3(5k). 12k + 24 = 15k. 24 = 3k. k = 8. Originally: 3(8) + 5(8) = 24 + 40 = 64 animals.
common_errors: Not using a multiplier (k) to represent the original ratio
Cross-multiplying incorrectly

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can share a quantity into a given ratio when the number of parts is small.
levels.example_task: Share £20 in the ratio 1:3.
levels.example_response: Total parts = 1 + 3 = 4. Each part = £20 ÷ 4 = £5. First share: 1 × £5 = £5. Second share: 3 × £5 = £15.
common_errors: Dividing by 3 instead of 4 (forgetting to add the ratio parts)
Giving both shares the same amount

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Divides quantities in ratios with two or three parts, checking the answers add to the original amount.
levels.example_task: Divide 360° in the ratio 2:3:4.
common_errors: Not adding all parts to find the total
Arithmetic errors in the division

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves ratio division problems in context, including finding one share when another is known.
levels.example_task: Amit and Beth share money in the ratio 5:3. Amit gets £30 more than Beth. How much does each get?
levels.example_response: Difference in parts: 5 - 3 = 2 parts = £30. So 1 part = £15. Amit: 5 × £15 = £75. Beth: 3 × £15 = £45. Check: £75 - £45 = £30 ✓.
common_errors: Dividing £30 by the total parts (8) instead of the difference in parts (2)
Not reading 'more than' as requiring a difference calculation

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves problems involving changing ratios and multi-step ratio reasoning.
levels.example_task: A drink is made from juice and water in the ratio 2:5. 200 ml of water is added to 350 ml of drink. What is the new ratio of juice to water?
levels.example_response: Original 350 ml in ratio 2:5: juice = 2/7 × 350 = 100 ml, water = 5/7 × 350 = 250 ml. After adding 200 ml water: juice = 100 ml, water = 250 + 200 = 450 ml. New ratio = 100:450 = 2:9.
common_errors: Not finding the original juice and water amounts from the ratio
Recalculating the ratio of the original 350 ml without adding the extra water

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Recognises that doubling one quantity and doubling the other keeps the same relationship — an early sense of multiplicative reasoning.
levels.example_task: If 3 apples cost 90p, how much do 6 apples cost?
levels.example_response: 6 is double 3, so the cost is double 90p = 180p = £1.80.
common_errors: Adding 90p instead of doubling (getting £1.80 is correct, but adding would give wrong logic)
Not recognising the doubling relationship

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Understands that ratios express multiplicative relationships and can use this to solve proportion problems.
levels.example_task: If 5 notebooks cost £4, how much do 8 notebooks cost?
levels.example_response: Cost per notebook = £4 ÷ 5 = £0.80. Cost of 8 = 8 × £0.80 = £6.40.
common_errors: Using additive reasoning (5→8 is +3, so £4 + £3 = £7)
Not finding the unit rate as an intermediate step

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Identifies and uses multiplicative relationships in ratio, fraction and algebraic contexts, distinguishing from additive relationships.
levels.example_task: y is proportional to x. When x = 4, y = 10. Find y when x = 14.
levels.example_response: y/x = 10/4 = 2.5 (constant multiplier). When x = 14: y = 14 × 2.5 = 35.
common_errors: Using additive reasoning: y increased by 10 when x increased by 4, so y increases by 25 when x increases by 10 (getting y = 35 by luck but wrong method)
Not identifying the constant of proportionality

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Distinguishes between additive, multiplicative, and other functional relationships, applying the correct reasoning in each case.
levels.example_task: Alice says: 'If I add 3 to x and also add 3 to y, the ratio stays the same.' Is Alice correct? Test with the ratio 2:5.
levels.example_response: Original ratio 2:5. Adding 3: 5:8. Is 5/8 = 2/5? 5/8 = 0.625, 2/5 = 0.4. No — the ratio has changed. Adding the same number to both parts of a ratio changes the ratio (this is additive reasoning, but ratios require multiplicative reasoning). To keep ratio 2:5, you must multiply both by the same factor: e.g. 4:10, 6:15, etc.
common_errors: Assuming additive changes preserve ratios
Not testing the claim with actual numbers

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can see that a ratio of 1:4 means one part out of five total, connecting to a simple fraction.
levels.example_task: In a ratio of 1:4, what fraction is the smaller part?
levels.example_response: Total parts = 1 + 4 = 5. The smaller part is 1/5.
common_errors: Writing 1/4 instead of 1/5
Confusing the ratio parts with the total

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converts between ratio and fraction notation and uses both to solve problems.
levels.example_task: Red paint and white paint are mixed in the ratio 2:3. What fraction of the mixture is red?
levels.example_response: Total = 2 + 3 = 5 parts. Red fraction = 2/5.
common_errors: Writing 2/3 (the ratio) instead of 2/5 (the fraction of the whole)
Not adding both parts to find the total

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Connects ratio, fraction and linear function representations, seeing a:b as equivalent to the function y = (a/b)x.
levels.example_task: The ratio of boys to girls is 3:5. If there are 40 girls, write a formula connecting boys (b) and girls (g).
common_errors: Writing b = (5/3)g (inverting the ratio)
Not recognising that the ratio gives a linear relationship

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses the connections between ratio, fraction and linear functions to solve complex problems and prove general results.
levels.example_task: If a:b = 3:4 and b:c = 2:5, find a:b:c.
levels.example_response: Make the b values equal. a:b = 3:4 and b:c = 2:5. LCM of 4 and 2 is 4. Scale second ratio: b:c = 4:10. Now a:b:c = 3:4:10. Check: a:b = 3:4 ✓, b:c = 4:10 = 2:5 ✓.
common_errors: Writing a:b:c = 3:2:5 (just joining the ratios without making b consistent)
Not scaling both ratios so the shared term matches

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can calculate a simple percentage increase or decrease given the percentage and the original amount.
levels.example_task: A shirt costs £40. It is reduced by 20%. What is the sale price?
common_errors: Computing 20% but forgetting to subtract it from the original
Computing 20% of the sale price instead of the original price

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses multipliers for percentage change (1.15 for a 15% increase, 0.85 for a 15% decrease) for efficiency.
levels.example_task: Increase £250 by 12%.
levels.example_response: Multiplier = 1.12. New amount = 250 × 1.12 = £280.
common_errors: Using 0.12 as the multiplier instead of 1.12
Computing 12% correctly but forgetting to add it to the original

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Finds the original value before a percentage change (reverse percentage) and solves simple interest problems.
levels.example_task: After a 15% increase, a price is £69. Find the original price.
levels.example_response: £69 = 115% of original. Original = £69 ÷ 1.15 = £60.
common_errors: Computing £69 - 15% of £69 = £58.65 (wrong — this subtracts 15% of the new price)
Not recognising that £69 represents 115% not 100%

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves compound percentage change problems and evaluates real-world financial situations critically.
levels.example_task: An investment of £5000 earns 3% compound interest per year. Find the value after 4 years.
levels.example_response: Value = 5000 × 1.03⁴ = 5000 × 1.12551 = £5627.54 (to nearest penny). The compound interest earned is £627.54. Simple interest would give 5000 × 0.03 × 4 = £600 — compound earns £27.54 more because interest earns interest.
common_errors: Computing simple interest (5000 × 0.03 × 4 = 600) instead of compound
Not raising the multiplier to the power of the number of years

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Recognises direct proportion in simple contexts: when one quantity doubles, the other doubles.
levels.example_task: If 4 oranges cost £2, how much do 12 oranges cost?
levels.example_response: 12 is 3 times 4, so the cost is 3 × £2 = £6.
common_errors: Using additive reasoning (12 - 4 = 8, so £2 + £8 = £10)
Not recognising the multiplicative relationship

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses the unitary method to solve direct proportion problems with non-simple multipliers.
levels.example_task: 7 identical books weigh 3.5 kg. How much do 11 books weigh?
levels.example_response: 1 book weighs 3.5 ÷ 7 = 0.5 kg. 11 books weigh 11 × 0.5 = 5.5 kg.
common_errors: Dividing 11 by 7 and multiplying by 3.5 incorrectly
Not finding the unit rate first

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves direct proportion problems algebraically using y = kx and identifies direct proportion from tables and graphs.
levels.example_task: y is directly proportional to x. When x = 6, y = 15. Find y when x = 10.
common_errors: Finding the ratio but not using it as the constant k
Not recognising that a graph through the origin indicates direct proportion

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies direct proportion in complex contexts including y ∝ x² and y ∝ √x, and distinguishes these from linear proportionality.
levels.example_task: The energy E of a moving object is directly proportional to the square of its speed v. When v = 4, E = 32. Find E when v = 10.
levels.example_response: E = kv². 32 = k(16), so k = 2. E = 2v². When v = 10: E = 2(100) = 200. Note: doubling speed quadruples energy — this is why speed limits matter for road safety.
common_errors: Using E = kv (linear) instead of E = kv² (quadratic)
Not squaring v when substituting

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands that in some situations, when one quantity increases the other decreases — the basic idea of inverse proportion.
levels.example_task: If 4 workers take 12 days to build a wall, will 8 workers take more or fewer days?
levels.example_response: Fewer days — more workers means the job is done faster. 8 workers is double, so the time halves: 6 days.
common_errors: Saying 8 workers take 24 days (doubling instead of halving)
Not recognising the inverse relationship

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solves inverse proportion problems using the unitary method: find the total work units first.
levels.example_task: 3 machines take 8 hours to complete a job. How long would 6 machines take?
levels.example_response: Total machine-hours = 3 × 8 = 24. With 6 machines: 24 ÷ 6 = 4 hours.
common_errors: Doubling the time because there are double the machines
Not computing the total constant (machine × hours)

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves inverse proportion problems algebraically using y = k/x and identifies inverse proportion from tables and graphs.
levels.example_task: y is inversely proportional to x. When x = 5, y = 12. Find y when x = 8.
common_errors: Writing y = k/x but computing k as y/x instead of xy
Confusing inverse proportion with negative proportion

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies inverse proportion in complex contexts including y ∝ 1/x², and compares direct and inverse proportion algebraically and graphically.
levels.example_task: The intensity of light I is inversely proportional to the square of the distance d from the source. At d = 2 m, I = 100 units. Find I at d = 5 m.
levels.example_response: I = k/d². 100 = k/4, so k = 400. At d = 5: I = 400/25 = 16 units. Moving from 2 m to 5 m (×2.5 distance) reduces intensity by 2.5² = 6.25 times: 100/6.25 = 16 ✓.
common_errors: Using I = k/d instead of I = k/d²
Not squaring the distance when substituting

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands that speed = distance ÷ time and can calculate speed in simple cases.
levels.example_task: A car travels 120 km in 2 hours. What is its speed?
levels.example_response: Speed = 120 ÷ 2 = 60 km/h.
common_errors: Computing 2 ÷ 120 (inverting distance and time)
Forgetting to include the units

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses compound units (speed, density, unit pricing) in straightforward calculations with unit conversions.
levels.example_task: Which is better value: 500g of cereal for £2.40 or 750g for £3.30?
common_errors: Comparing total prices without adjusting for quantity
Computing the ratio the wrong way round

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves multi-step problems using compound units, including those requiring unit conversions and formula rearrangement.
levels.example_task: A metal block has mass 540g and volume 200 cm³. Find its density. Could it be aluminium (density 2.7 g/cm³)?
levels.example_response: Density = mass/volume = 540/200 = 2.7 g/cm³. Yes, it matches aluminium's density.
common_errors: Computing volume/mass instead of mass/volume
Not converting units when mass is in kg and volume in cm³

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies compound measures in complex real-world problems, interpreting graphs of compound measures and converting between systems.
levels.example_task: A runner completes 5 km in 22 minutes and 30 seconds. Express this as (a) min/km (b) km/h (c) m/s.
levels.example_response: (a) 22.5 min ÷ 5 = 4.5 min/km. (b) 5 km in 22.5 min = 5 ÷ (22.5/60) = 5 ÷ 0.375 = 13.33 km/h. (c) 5000 m ÷ 1350 s = 3.70 m/s (2 d.p.). Each unit tells a different story: pace (min/km) is useful for runners, km/h for comparing with traffic, m/s for physics.
common_errors: Not converting 22 min 30 sec to 22.5 minutes
Mixing up the conversions between the three forms

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can solve simple money problems involving the four operations.
levels.example_task: You buy 3 items at £4.50 each and pay with a £20 note. How much change do you get?
common_errors: Multiplying incorrectly (e.g. 3 × 4.5 = 12)
Not subtracting from the amount paid

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solves financial problems involving percentages, such as discounts, VAT and simple profit/loss.
levels.example_task: A shopkeeper buys goods for £60 and sells them for £78. What is the percentage profit?
levels.example_response: Profit = £78 - £60 = £18. Percentage profit = (18/60) × 100 = 30%.
common_errors: Computing 18/78 × 100 (using selling price instead of cost price)
Confusing profit with revenue

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves problems involving simple and compound interest, understanding the difference between the two.
levels.example_task: £2000 is invested at 4% simple interest. How much is the investment worth after 3 years?
levels.example_response: Interest per year = 4% of £2000 = £80. Total interest over 3 years = £240. Value = £2000 + £240 = £2240.
common_errors: Applying compound interest instead of simple interest
Computing 4% of the accumulated amount each year instead of the original

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves complex financial problems including repeated percentage change, comparing financial products, and understanding the time value of money.
levels.example_task: Bank A offers 3.5% compound interest. Bank B offers 3.8% simple interest. For a £10,000 deposit over 5 years, which is better?
levels.example_response: Bank A (compound): 10000 × 1.035⁵ = 10000 × 1.18769 = £11,876.86. Bank B (simple): 10000 + 10000 × 0.038 × 5 = 10000 + 1900 = £11,900. Bank B is better for 5 years. However, compound overtakes simple eventually — at year 12: A = 10000 × 1.035¹² = £15,111 vs B = 10000 + 4560 = £14,560.
common_errors: Assuming compound is always better (it depends on the rate difference and time period)
Not computing both precisely for comparison

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can identify whether a problem requires addition or multiplication, but does not yet distinguish additive from multiplicative reasoning explicitly.
levels.example_task: Tom has 8 sweets. He gets 3 more. How many now? Tom has 8 sweets. He triples his collection. How many now?
levels.example_response: First: 8 + 3 = 11 (additive — adding a fixed amount). Second: 8 × 3 = 24 (multiplicative — scaling by a factor).
common_errors: Not seeing the structural difference between the two types
Using addition for both problems

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Distinguishes between additive and multiplicative comparison, choosing the correct approach for proportion problems.
levels.example_task: Recipe for 4 people uses 300g flour. How much for 6 people? Is this additive or multiplicative?
levels.example_response: This is multiplicative: 6/4 = 1.5 times as many people, so 300 × 1.5 = 450g flour. If it were additive, we would add a fixed amount regardless of the number of people — that doesn't make sense for recipes.
common_errors: Using additive reasoning: 6-4=2 extra people, so 300 + 2 = 302g
Not recognising the scaling structure

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Identifies the correct reasoning type (additive, multiplicative, or proportional) for a given problem and explains why.
levels.example_task: Ava is 10 and her brother is 6. In 4 years, will the age difference or the age ratio be the same?
levels.example_response: Difference now: 10-6=4. In 4 years: 14-10=4. The difference stays the same (additive relationship — ages increase by the same amount). Ratio now: 10/6 = 5/3. In 4 years: 14/10 = 7/5. The ratio changes. Ages have an additive relationship (constant difference), not a multiplicative one.
common_errors: Thinking the ratio stays the same
Not distinguishing between constant difference (additive) and constant ratio (multiplicative)

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Analyses complex situations requiring a combination of additive and multiplicative reasoning, and identifies which type applies at each step.
levels.example_task: A pool is filled by two pipes. Pipe A fills it in 6 hours, Pipe B in 4 hours. How long to fill it together? What type of reasoning is needed?
levels.example_response: This is a rates problem (multiplicative). Pipe A fills 1/6 per hour, Pipe B fills 1/4 per hour. Together: 1/6 + 1/4 = 2/12 + 3/12 = 5/12 per hour. Time = 12/5 = 2.4 hours = 2 hours 24 minutes. The addition of rates (1/6 + 1/4) is additive, but the rates themselves are multiplicative (fraction of pool per hour). This problem requires both types of reasoning working together.
common_errors: Adding the times (6 + 4 = 10 hours) instead of adding the rates
Computing 6 × 4 / (6+4) = 2.4 without understanding why this formula works
